name: Vitaly Abalakov
content:
Vitaly Mikhaylovich Abalakov (Russian: Вита́лий Миха́йлович Абала́ков) (13 January [O.S. 31 December] 1906 in Krasnoyarsk – 26 May 1986 in Moscow[1]) was a Soviet chemical engineer, mountaineer and inventor.
 Brother of Yevgeniy Abalakov, another famous alpinist, he made the first Soviet ascent of Lenin Peak in 1934 and two more ascents of this mountain. In 1936 he also made the ascent of Khan Tengri, where he lost several fingers and part of his foot.[2]
 In 1938, he and others from his team were arrested by NKVD and were under investigation until 1940. He was accused of "open public propaganda" of western mountaineering techniques and "diminishing" domestic alpinists' achievements and being a "German spy".
 Abalakov is credited with such inventions as camming devices in the 1930s, Abalakov thread (or V-thread) gearless ice climbing anchor, and many other climbing equipment innovations.[3][4]
 
 This biographical article relating to a Russian sportsperson is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. This biographical article relating to climbing or mountaineering is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it.

Vitaly Mikhaylovich AbalakovBorn (1906-01-13) January 13, 1906 (age 115)Krasnoyarsk, Yenisei Province, Russian EmpireDied (1986-05-26) 26 May 1986 (age 34)Moscow, Russian SFSR, USSRAlma materD. Mendeleev University of Chemical Technology of RussiaOccupationchemical engineer, mountaineer and inventor
Vitaly Mikhaylovich Abalakov (Russian: Вита́лий Миха́йлович Абала́ков) (13 January [O.S. 31 December] 1906 in Krasnoyarsk – 26 May 1986 in Moscow[1]) was a Soviet chemical engineer, mountaineer and inventor.
Brother of Yevgeniy Abalakov, another famous alpinist, he made the first Soviet ascent of Lenin Peak in 1934 and two more ascents of this mountain. In 1936 he also made the ascent of Khan Tengri, where he lost several fingers and part of his foot.[2]
In 1938, he and others from his team were arrested by NKVD and were under investigation until 1940. He was accused of "open public propaganda" of western mountaineering techniques and "diminishing" domestic alpinists' achievements and being a "German spy".
Abalakov is credited with such inventions as camming devices in the 1930s, Abalakov thread (or V-thread) gearless ice climbing anchor, and many other climbing equipment innovations.[3][4]

Honoured Master of Sports of the USSR (1943)
Honoured Trainer of the USSR (1961)
